channel.title: BBC Sport

item.title: Will Scotland's luck hold for biggest test of World Cup dream?
item.description: Scotland are ideally positioned to qualify for the World Cup finals, but Steve Clarke's side now face the hardest part of their journey, writes Tom English.

item.title: Title race, crossovers & goals - what to expect from Manchester derby
item.description: Will Man Utd help knock Man City off their perch at the top of the WSL table? Or will City land a lethal blow to the Red Devils' title aspirations?

item.title: NI focus on play-off after Slovakia sucker punch
item.description: With Northern Ireland now guaranteed a World Cup play-off in March, BBC Sport NI's Jonathan Bradley reflects on their qualifying campaign.

item.title: Why has Sweden's World Cup bid gone wrong and can Potter save them?
item.description: Graham Potter was appointed Sweden manager in October after spells at West Ham and Chelsea. Is he the perfect fit?

item.title: Banned Bellamy's fire still burns in Liechtenstein
item.description: Banned Wales boss Craig Bellamy will have to watch Saturday's World Cup qualifier in Liechtenstein from the stands, having been suspended as a player when they were last in Vaduz.

item.title: 'All or nothing' for Republic of Ireland in Hungary
item.description: Republic of Ireland winger Chiedozie Ogbene accepts Sunday's final World Cup qualifying game against Hungary in Budapest is "all or nothing".

item.title: WSL derby win 'not impossible' for Spurs
item.description: This time last season Tottenham were struggling in the Women's Super League. But with a new manager and fresh belief, this season they are in top-four contention.

item.title: Seven games, 20 goals, none conceded - England close in on perfection
item.description: England have cruised through World Cup qualifying, winning all seven of their games and scoring 20 unanswered goals, setting several records and leaving them on the cusp of another.

item.title: Referee needed to 'be stronger' - O'Neill
item.description: Northern Ireland manager Michael O'Neill says the yellow card he was shown at the end of his side's 1-0 defeat by Slovakia was for telling the referee to "be stronger".

item.title: Le Tissier on her and stepbrother Alex Scott's unique football journey
item.description: Manchester United and England defender Maya le Tissier reflects on her experiences growing up in Guernsey with stepbrother and Bournemouth midfielder Alex Scott who has recently received his first call-up for England.

item.title: Alex Scott takes on Australian 'This or That?'
item.description: Football Focus presenter Alex Scott prepares for jungle life in I'm a Celebrity Get Me Out Of Here as she takes on an Australian-themed "This or That?".

item.title: Harder & Carmona star in Champions League best goals
item.description: Watch the best goals from the latest round of fixtures from the Women's Champions League, including Olga Carmona's screamer for Paris St-Germain and Pernille Harder's equaliser against Arsenal.

item.title: I feel part of a big football nation - Bellamy
item.description: Wales boss Craig Bellamy says he feels part of a big football nation now as his side battle to finish second in their World Cup qualifying group.

item.title: It's about building a team - Tuchel on win over Serbia
item.description: England manager Thomas Tuchel says he is "building a team" and asking the players to leave their egos behind after Thursday's 2-0 win over Serbia.

item.title: Croatia join the party - what's still at stake in final World Cup qualifiers?
item.description: BBC Sport's Ask Me Anything team looks at who has qualified for next year's Fifa World Cup.

item.title: 'Proper footballers and me' - Fifa award nomination shocks Brentford's Cheatley
item.description: Brentford's Ashley Cheatley is on Fifa's shortlist for the annual Marta Award after scoring one of the best goals by women worldwide.

item.title: Liverpool want Olise to replace Salah - Saturday's gossip
item.description: Bayern Munich winger Michael Olise interests Liverpool, Arsenal and Manchester United eye Borussia Dortmund forward Karim Adeyemi, Newcastle are chasing AZ Alkmaar midfielder Kees Smit, plus more.

item.title: How can Northern Ireland qualify for the 2026 World Cup?
item.description: With two World Cup qualifying fixtures remaining, where do Northern Ireland stand in the play-off picture for the tournament next summer?

item.title: Easy friendlies or tough opposition? England's World Cup dilemma
item.description: England have been able to start preparing for the World Cup for months, but the task of picking warm-up games is tricky. BBC Sport assesses some of the options.

item.title: 'National League is League Three' - inside non-league's 3UP campaign
item.description: National League clubs are ramping up the pressure on the EFL to increase the number of promotion places into League Two.

item.title: The painful slow death of a playing career after World Cup highs
item.description: After two years of struggling to overcome a career-ending injury, ex-Wales midfielder Joe Morrell is now pursuing a passion for coaching.

item.title: 'Where do we look now?' Heskey on lack of England strikers
item.description: Emile Heskey feels it is difficult to see who the next main England striker will be, following the decline of the traditional number nine.

item.title: Rice, Yamal and Brentford women's goal among Puskas & Marta nominees
item.description: Brentford women's Ashley Cheatley is included alongside Declan Rice and Lamine Yamal on Fifa's shortlist for the best goals of the past year.

item.title: Chelsea's Hampton to miss 'few weeks' with quad injury
item.description: Hannah Hampton could miss England's upcoming friendlies against China and Ghana after Sonia Bompastor confirms she has sustained a quad injury.

item.title: Guehi leaves England squad because of injury
item.description: Marc Guehi withdraws from the England squad because of injury and will continue his rehabilitation with Crystal Palace.

item.title: 'Maybe I got in Ronaldo's head' - managers react to Portugal star's red
item.description: Portugal captain Cristiano Ronaldo was sent off in his side's defeat against the Republic of Ireland but was it deserved?

item.title: Swans hold talks with Hellberg over manager role
item.description: Swansea City hold talks with Kim Hellberg, the boss of Swedish top-flight side Hammarby, as they seek a replacement for Alan Sheehan.

item.title: Sheff Wed wages to be paid on time thanks to fans
item.description: Wages at Sheffield Wednesday can be paid on time for November and December after fans ended their boycott of the club.

item.title: Warne driven by feelings of 'impostor syndrome'
item.description: MK Dons boss Paul Warne is approaching 450 games in management but admits he still suffers from 'impostor syndrome'.

item.title: Rangers call for Collum talks after ref chief backs Trusty decision
item.description: Rangers want further talks with Willie Collum after the Scottish FA's head of referees backed his match officials over the decision not to show a red card to Celtic's Auston Trusty in the Ibrox side's Premier Sports Cup semi-final defeat.

item.title: 'I was stupid to bet, but gambling ads are everywhere'
item.description: Lewis Macari admits he was "stupid" to bet on football at the start of his career, but felt gambling on the sport was unavoidable when constantly exposed to it.

item.title: Five things to look out for in EFL: Imps eye top spot as Millers motor
item.description: BBC Sport highlights five things you might want to look out for in this weekend's EFL action

item.title: Coventry's Lampard named manager of the month
item.description: After steering Championship leaders Coventry City to five wins out of six, Frank Lampard is named manager of the month for October.

item.title: 'I got his shirt' - Carragher on Malta & Lewandowski
item.description: Not many League One defenders have played against one of the world's best strikers, but James Carragher - son of ex-England international Jamie - has the shirt to prove it.

item.title: Drenthe on course for 'successful recovery' from stroke
item.description: Royston Drenthe's manager remains confident the former Real Madrid and Everton winger will make "a successful recovery" after his stroke.

item.title: Aberdeen report £2m loss for cup-winning season
item.description: Scottish Cup winners Aberdeen report a £2m loss for the year to June, after a season without European football but with an increase in player trading profit.

item.title: Why EFL matches get postponed for international call-ups
item.description: BBC Sport's Ask Me Anything team explains why some League One and League two matches get postponed due to international call-ups.

item.title: Is anything being done about poor player behaviour?
item.description: Player behaviour didn't feature in Reinventing Football, our manifesto for the game, but it was a big focus for fans.

item.title: 'VAR has to rein its neck in' - how I'd change football for the fans
item.description: In his BBC Sport column, former Premier League manager Tony Pulis looks at which laws he would change in football.

item.title: Could a stopped clock end time-wasting in football?
item.description: Would a game of two halves of 30 minutes, with the watch stopped when the ball is out, really improve football?

item.title: How new rules would change way football is played
item.description: BBC Sport has been looking at possible ways of changing football - but what impact could different laws have on tactics?

item.title: The Ratcliffe revolution - inside Man Utd's exodus and rebuild
item.description: BBC Sport tells the story of how Sir Jim Ratcliffe ripped apart and rebuilt Manchester United's leadership team.

item.title: The great number nine decline - where have England's strikers gone?
item.description: BBC Sport takes an in-depth look at why England lack centre-forward options behind Harry Kane - a far cry from when the likes of Les Ferdinand only won 17 caps.

item.title: Meet the man who played in two games, in two countries... in one day
item.description: BBC Sport tells the story of Soren Lerby, who once played for Denmark and Bayern Munich on the same day - in different countries.

item.title: Former defender Edwards' return to Wolves - a gamble all round?
item.description: Wolves finally have their man. But how big a gamble have the Premier League side made in appointing Rob Edwards?

item.title: 1,000 games in, Guardiola has new energy for new era
item.description: Sunday began with a celebration of Pep Guardiola and ended in the same manner, with the Manchester City boss showing he has new energy in a new era for the club.

item.title: Transfers - September to December 2025
item.description: Check out the significant signings and departures in the Premier League, Scottish Premiership, EFL and Women's Super League.

item.title: Manager ins and outs - 2025-26 season
item.description: BBC Sport tracks all the manager ins and outs in the Premier League, Scottish Premiership, Women's Super League, English Football League and National League.

item.title: Why are England called the Three Lions?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team explain where the three lions on the England shirt came from.

item.title: When is the 2026 World Cup draw?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team explore when the World Cup draw is, how the seeding works and who has qualified so far.

item.title: Who is Wilfried Nancy?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team take a look who MLS manager Wilfried Nancy is.

item.title: Why VAR gets involved in some penalties but not others
item.description: It was a weekend of VAR penalty decisions in the Premier League, with spot-kicks awarded, cancelled and ignored. BBC Sport explains why.

item.title: Why can Channel Islands players play for England?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team look at why players born in the Channel Islands like Alex Scott can represent England at a senior level.

item.title: What are the Fifa Best Awards?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team explain what the Fifa Best Awards are, who can vote and who the nominees are.

item.title: Why do footballers tape up their wrists?
item.description: Our Ask Me Anything team explains why footballers use tape to wrap their wrists.

item.title: Celtic granted permission to speak to Nancy - gossip
item.description: Speculation ramps up over Celtic's pursuit of next manager as Scottish Premiership midfielders' futures are assessed.

item.title: 'Mad scientist' & 'next Luis Enrique' - who is Celtic-linked Wilfried Nancy?
item.description: Kheredine Idessane speaks to an MLS expert about Columbus Crew head coach Wilfried Nancy, who has been linked with Celtic.

item.title: Maccabi fan ban was due to hooliganism, say police
item.description: West Midlands Police did not previously reveal its reasons because "it wasn't deemed helpful".

item.title: Referees among suspects sought in match-fixing probe
item.description: Turkish prosecutors issue detention orders for 21 people - including 17 referees and two club presidents - as part of a major investigation into betting and match fixing.

item.title: 'Historically for men' - WSL wants stadium changes
item.description: The company which runs English professional women's football calls for more female-friendly stadiums.

item.title: From farming village to Liverpool icon - the Salah story
item.description: BBC Sport visits Egypt to discover what Mohamed Salah means to the people of the football-mad country, and how a small boy from humble beginnings became a national icon.

item.title: Napoli 'smell blood' & target Premier League's discarded stars
item.description: After Scott McTominay was a hit, Napoli went back to the Premier League for Kevin de Bruyne, could more players follow them to Serie A?

item.title: How does Daniel Levy run Tottenham - and would he ever leave?
item.description: With Tottenham struggling on the pitch and chairman Daniel Levy facing criticism from fans, BBC Sport looks at how the club is run and what the future might hold.

item.title: When River Plate icon Diaz took over fourth-tier Oxford
item.description: Twenty years on from Ramon Diaz's surprising appointment at Oxford United, BBC Sport looks at what happened and how it went.

item.title: East meets west London - the mentor who changed Chelsea
item.description: Vinay Menon knew nothing about football when he went for a meeting at a west London mansion in 2009. A few weeks later he was in the heart of the Chelsea dressing room.

item.title: The air crash and the underdogs - a triumph for a lost generation
item.description: Nineteen years and 10 miles separated Zambia's football team from a lost, golden generation on a fateful night in Libreville.

item.title: The rise and fall of North Korea - the sleeping giant of women's football
item.description: North Korea lags behind most of the rest of the world in several areas. But the hermit state has had an outsized impact on international women's football.
